page.title: 03ECOLOGY OF CRUWYS MORCHARD
page.content: The land is mainly improved grassland but there are some broadleaved woodlands. In these oak is dominant, supporting the richest diversity of animal species, also beech, which is faster growing and does not allow much ground cover, its thick foliage stopping the light. Other important broadleaves are ash and sycamore. Beech and sycamore are both introduced species. Other ecologically significant areas are the acidic marshy grasslands along the edges of streams, supporting wetland species of plants and animals. The variety of vegetation in the hedgerows is very important for wildlife, providing shelter, food and breeding grounds, also corridors along which they can travel undetected. Red and roe deer frequent the woodlands and buzzards nest locally.
